--Road Rally: You are the driver of a road rally sports car. You must move your car through a designated course in the shortest length of time without crashing. A very difficult task - you may be killed!

--Challenge Cup: You are the skipper of a racing sloop competing in a challenge cup race. You must sail against obstacles to win.

--Boarding Party: The German U-Boat 103 has been depth bombed and the crew has abandoned ship. They set a time bomb that you and the crew of the USS Fletcher must disarm before the submarine is blown up. You may be killed in the process!

--Medic: A member of your infantry unit is wounded. Your mission, Captain, is to have your medical corpsman retrieve the soldier; however, the enemy is determined that you will not do it, and will do everything possible to stop you!

--Kamikaze: During a battle your carrier has become isolated from the main fleet. You are under attack by Japanese suicide squadrons that you must destroy before they sink your carrier. The odds are against you!

--Tank Corps: The US Patton tanks against the German Panzers. You are the commander of an American Tank Squad that has met the killer Panzers and you must destroy them before they destroy you. They have very important advantages against you!

--Three Day Battle: You are the Confederate General Lee attempting to break the famous fishhook line established by Union General Meade at Gettysburg. If you break through, then Washington falls. You must battle for three days. Your best chance for success is to win the first battle before Union gains strength. Will you be able to do it?

--Iron Ships: You are the captain of the Confederate iron-clad ship Virginia in 1862. You must defeat the Union ship Monitor before you can enter the shipping lanes and sink the ships that are helping the Union cause. Can you break the Union blockade?

--Rescue: As the commander of a Federation Starship your shuttle is out on a mission. The shuttle was disabled by a Klingon Warship. You must rescue the shuttle, which is set as a trap for you, and return to the base with it for repair before your starship is destroyed. The enemy is waiting for you!
23719.name: Solo Games

23720.name: Family Jewels
23720.description: The sexy who, where, what and which adult mystery game. Includes game board, 6 game pieces, 13 playing chips, 29 playing cards and rule sheet. For 3-6 players.

23721.name: Mensch ärgere dich nicht: Das Knobelspiel
23721.description:
Each player has 5 dice with letters a, b, c, d, e, and e. Goal is to collect the letters in that order.

When rolling you (remaining) dice, you can substitute some of them with dice from other players. In this case, they might loose part of the set they already collected (depending on your roll).

23722.name: Jerry Kramer's Instant Replay
23722.description:
The exciting strategy football game for "pro-watchers" of all ages"

"I'm proud to have had a part in the making of this game. While it is professional and realistic, the rules are simple enough that young and old can learn to play and enjoy it. Sharpen your competitive spirit, and good luck in outsmarting your opponent." - Jerry Kramer (former Green Bay Packer)

23723.name: Dinosaurs Extinct?
23723.description:
2 to 4 players compete in this roll and move children's game. The object is to be the first dinosaur to move from the prehistoric era to the 21st century with a live dinosaur. Along the way you'll have to fight the other dinosaurs and get past various "earth events". The earth events include "ice ages, volcanoes, earthquakes and meteorites". The game board also features "dino switch" spaces where you get to switch positions with another player's dinosaur and Time warp spaces, where you move ahead or fall back.

Players may choose to be a Triceratops, Stegosaurus, Corythosaurus, or an Apatosaurus.

Each of the 4 Dinosaurs has a colorful card with overlays. The base card shows the Dinosaur bones, the overlay shows the Dinosaur alive. As you get closer to extinction, you flip over the overlays to expose the fossil bones.

For ages 5 and up.

23724.name: Dragon Chess
23724.description:
Dragon Chess has the same set of rules as Chess. However, the playing field has 124 squares. There are two Dragons per player, each with a Pawn located on the rank in front of the Dragon. The Dragon occupies the outer two squares on the same rank as the King.
The Field has two extra ranks (rows) and files (columns) as well as two flanks each with 12 squares located on either side of the main playing area proving a total playing area of 124 squares.

The Dragon moves and captures on the rank (horizontally), file (vertically) and diagonally, over unoccupied squares and limited to three squares in line.

23725.name: Re-Route: The Marching Season Game
23725.description:
Re-Route: The Marching Season Game covers 10 weeks during the 12th July Orange Marches in Northern Ireland when passions and sectarianism are inflamed. The game is set in a typical year during the wost disturbances sparked by the annual Drumcree Orange Parade along the Garvaghy Road (1995-2000).

The game requires 3 players: The Loyalist player represents certain members of the Protestant community in Northern Ireland, such as the Orange Order, and various paramilitaries (e.g. UVF, LVF, UFF, RHC). The Republican player represents certain members of the Catholic community in the Occupied Six Counties, such as Residents' Groups, and various paramilitaries (e.g. pIRA, cIRA, rIRA, INLA). The final player represents the Royal Ulster Constabulary police force (RUC). The Republican and Loyalist players use cards to influence regions on a map of Northern Ireland, reacting to one another and actions of the RUC player whose objective, in this game, is to reduce the influence of both the Loyalists and the Republicans.

The crux of the game is in judicious playing of the cards: The Loyalists play a March card in Armagh - will you, as the RUC player, allow it to go ahead and risk a Republican Riot; or do you Re-Route that March and risk a Loyalist reaction that may itself provoke a worse Republican reaction?
Should have kept that Tear-Gas card...

23726.name: I Giochi del 2000: Atlantic Wars
23726.description: A small set of rules for playing with miniatures in scale HO and 1/32.

23727.name: It-DAH-gan
23727.description: There are 60 cards with ranks from 1 to 15, quantities ranging from two 1's up to six 15's; 15 of the cards are worth a point each. All cards are dealt out. The player receiving the 15 marked "star-DAH" begins by playing any number of 15's. Each player in turn then either passes or plays the same amount of cards as the last set played, but with a lower rank. When all but one players have passed, the last one to play takes all the cards played and starts a new trick with one or more cards of the same rank. The round continues until all players are out of cards; then point cards taken are scored. The first player to go out begins the next round by getting the two best (i.e., lowest-numbered) cards from the last player to go out, giving any two in return; likewise, the second to go out gets the best card from the next-to-last to go out. (With three players, the first and last to go out exchange one card.) Play continues until one player reaches 50 points.

23728.name: Balanko
23728.description:
Balanko is touted as a "new classic from the very first turn" by its designer. It is a straightforward manual dexterity game created by Canadian designer Jamie MacKinnon.

The game is mounted upon the box it is packaged in and consists of a rail upon which a steel ball rolls, a second tethered steel ball, ten scoring bins (50, 100, 150, 200 respectively), and two scoring tracks.

One player begins by releasing the steel ball from its holster, allowing it to roll along the rail. The other player then attempts to knock said ball into one of the various scoring bins using the tethered ball; if that player misses, the other player may catch the swinging, tethered ball and immediately try their hand at knocking the rolling ball into a bin.

Play continues until one of the two players succeeds in scoring. The object is to accumulate 1500 points (though any total works nicely). It's harder than it sounds!

Balanko is wonderfully simple and accessible to almost anyone regardless of age (a suggested age of 3+ is more because of reasonably small pieces than anything else). As it mounts directly onto its packaging, it's easily stored when not in use.

23729.name: Charge to Glory: The Battle of New Market
23729.description:
Charge to Glory: The Battle of New Market, is a tactical level game simulating the Battle of New Market, May 15, 1864. This battle, which is famous for its charge by the VMI Cadet Corps, prolonged the Civil War by about an additional year as it protected the Confederate bread basket, the Shenandoah Valley in Virginia. The game itself is typical military/wargame fare, but the subject battle is one that is often overlooked.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 6 minutes approximately
Hex: 40 yards
Elevation: 40 feet
Units: Company / Squadron / Section

Contents:
One 22"x34" map
Two countersheets (300 1/2" counters)
One 16 page Rulebook
One 2 page Introductory Game Rulebook
One Union OB Roster sheet
One Confederate OB Roster sheet

boardgamehonor: 2007 Mensa Select Winner
23730.description:
The players are gods at the dawn of time, creating earth's landscape and inhabiting it with people. They can command the creation and destruction of continents and the rise and fall of civilizations.

As gods, players seek to gain followers among the civilizations. They offer those followers luxuries, and oversee the building of pyramids and temples on their continents. In the end, the god with the most loyal, wealthy, and powerful followers will become ruler of gods, and wins the game...

Play involves placing triangular tiles to form islands, coastlines and continents. Players can also replace tiles to reform the topography of the planet.

Each civilization is represented by a color, and once a civilization is “born” a player can gain worshipers in that civilization, which in turn may score points for that player in various ways.

The placement or replacement of tiles may result in civilizations migrating, or going to war with other civilizations. These things are resolved by the various icons on the tiles.

The game is fairly simple, but offers quite a lot of tactical possibilities.
23730.name: Gheos
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGB Volume 28 - Gheos, Pieces of Eight, Der Elefant im Porzellanladen

23731.name: Peter Gunn Detective Game
23731.description: The Peter Gunn Detective Game is based on the highly successful Peter Gunn Television series from the early 1960's. Craig Stevens' character features prominently on the box of this licensed board game for kids 7-14. Each player takes a piece and start in the center of the board. A face-down person (Mr. Aay, Mr. Bee, Mr. Cee, Mr. Dee) and a face-down weapon (hammer, gun, knife, poison) are laid about on the board, and each player gets 2 cards, one showing which person to find, and one showing which weapon to find. Players spin the spinner to move around the board, looking at the face-down pieces in each area until they find the 2 on their cards. They then return to the center, reveal their cards, and tell the other players where their weapon and person are on the board. If they succeed, they win! If they declare wrong they are eliminated.

23732.name: Wild Woods Game
23732.description:
Storm clouds are on the horizon. In this game, players work together or on their own to get the forest animals back to their den in the Big Tree before the storm begins.

This game includes rules for multiple variants.

23733.description:
From the Avalanche Press website:

At the turn of the last century, South America seemed poised to make the same economic leap as the northern half of the hemisphere. Fueled by booming exports of grain, cattle, coffee and rubber, Brazil and Argentina saw their economies grow rapidly and at one time both stood among the world's ten wealthiest nations. All that cash led their leaders to seek the prestige symbols of the day: dreadnought battleships. Argentina, Brazil and Chile all built dreadnoughts just like the Great Powers, but none of them ever fired a shot at a foreign enemy.

Cone of Fire is a boxed game for both the Second World War at Sea and Great War at Sea series. The fleets of Argentina, Brazil and Chile plus those of Peru and Uruguay are added to both series, along with ships from Germany, France and Britain. Most of the scenarios, or game situations, are based on hypothetical situations arising from the actual war scares between the South American nations and sometimes European interlopers, and the war plans with which they addressed them. There are also scenarios based on the actual conflicts which took place in South American waters: the hunt for Admiral Maximilian Graf von Spee's German cruiser squadron in 1914, and the hunt for the cruiser that bore his name 25 years later.

Alongside the ships actually operated by the South American naval powers, there are also ships they ordered and did not receive, or contemplated but did not order. The Brazilians have several projected classes of battleships that they never completed, as well as the modern warships they sought from the U.S. Navy during World War II. Argentina and Chile have their projected battleships, carriers and cruisers as well. And there are the actual jet aircraft flown by Argentina and Brazil.

There are six maps, three at Second World War at Sea scale, and three at Great War at Sea scale. These cover the region from south of Tierra del Fuego, the southernmost tip of the Americas, to well north of Rio de Janeiro. There are huge stretches of ocean as well as the narrow, winding channels of the Chilean coast.
23733.name: Great War at Sea / Second World War at Sea: Cone of Fire
boardgameexpansion: Great War at Sea: Confederate States Navy (Second Edition)
Second World War at Sea: South American Navies
Second World War at Sea: Strait of Magellan
boardgameaccessory: Second World War at Sea: Transports

23734.name: Play & Learn the Childcraft Quiz Game
23734.description:
Play and Learn is a trivia game based on the Worldbook 'How & Why' library of children's encyclopedias.
Players move around a square board and depending where they land are required to take a volume of the World Book encyclopedias and then answer a question after being directed to the required page by the cards.

23735.description:
Suffren in India is a wargame (for 2 players) published in French magazine Vae Victis #34.

It is dedicated to the incredible naval campaign in India (1782-1783), where two equally able admirals fought each other: Hugues for the English side, Suffren for the French side.
23735.name: Suffren aux Indes

23736.name: Missionary Conquest
23736.description:
Each player is an American Christian missionary with the goal of visiting a number of countries on short-term mission trips. Various cards that are drawn poke fun of common experiences of those who go on short-term mission trips, including setbacks in raising money to go on the trip, and (in another country) finding out that the local cuisine does not agree with your stomach.

If you're behind in the game, you can go to a country that does not welcome outside religions - if you are martyred you get an extra bonus. You'd be out of the game but might win posthumously.

23737.name: Favored of Zeus
23737.description:
From their website.

Favored of Zeus is a card game for two to five people in which you take the place of one of the gods of Olympus. Zeus has declared a challenge among his gods and goddesses to be the first to gather one-hundred thousand followers.

To aid you in this task, you are allowed to choose one amongst the mortals who will champion your cause. This mortal will fight off the obstacles placed in your way by competitors as well as quest to increase your reputation. Along the way your hero can encounter allies to aid him, and you may take control of mighty Creatures that can make your obstacles more difficult for opponents or attack opponents' followers directly.

All you need to play are the cards, two six-sided dice, the game boards for each god, and something to use as a counter for each player (a penny or dime works well). An average game takes 30-60 minutes.

23738.name: Soul Sight CCG
23738.description: Soul Sight CCG (Customizable Card Game) is a Bible based card game. The cards are put into ply via the quoting of scripture. This game is heavy on memorization. Memory skills and deck building make this a game for ages 8-adult.

23739.name: Geoclues
23739.description:
You're on a deserted island. But don't worry, you're not stranded - you're with friends and family and you're having fun. You're playing a game where players hide "caches" (treasure chests) for each other to find. The caches contain coins and clues, and you'll use your navigational skills to tour the island and find them. The first person to collect a coin from each player and follow the clues to the "mystery cache" wins the game.

Home Page : http://www.scholartainment.com/pgc.html

23740.name: Les Aigles: supplément numéro 1
23740.description:
Les Aigles: Supplément numéro 1 is an addon booklet for Les Aigles. Inside, you can find:

- 14 scenarios
- 2 new army lists (Russia and Austria)
- Colored army chits to use instead of figures for playing the booklet scenarios.

As with a lot of Jeux Descartes wargames, the content is both in French and English.

Expands

Les Aigles

boardgamecompilation: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot Deluxe Limited Edition
23741.description:
The Ominous Onyx Booster Deck is the final installment to the Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot game. It was released in 2007 and is a double-sized booster with 110 cards.

Expands:

Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot
23741.name: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot: Ominous Onyx Booster
boardgameexpansion: Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot

23742.name: Ironclads: Hearts of Iron
23742.description:
From the Publisher's website:

"Behind wooden walls beat hearts of iron..."

— Austrian Admiral Wilhelm von Tegetthoff,
private letter to his mistress, June 1866

In the summer of 1866, the Austrian fleet fought the Italians in the first open-sea battle between ironclad fleets, at Lissa in the Adriatic. An Austrian victory, it prevented Italian seizure of the strategic island of Lissa.

Hearts of Iron is loosely based on the Great War at Sea series of games. The operational part of the game is very similar; there is an operational map of the Adriatic and central Mediterranean, on which fleets move and attempt to make contact. The tactical part of the game is more detailed, with armor (or lack of it), rifled and smooth-bore ordinance, ship maneuvering and leadership playing much more prominent roles.

In addition to the Austrian and Italian fleets, there is the American Mediterranean Squadron that the Austrians believed would fight alongside the Italians, and the Turkish European Fleet that entered the Adriatic to support Austria. Plus the British Mediterranean Fleet and a large French contingent, along with the Greeks, Egyptians and several other smaller navies. There are a wide variety of both operational and battle scenarios, based on extensive archival research into the original reports and dispatches of the Austro-Italian conflict along with many hypothetical engagements.

23743.name: Motoring
23743.description:
A circa 1930's English Spears board game.

Roll the dice and move your markers on the bright artwork board, to simulate taking a trip through the countryside. Various events can occur during your trip, depending on where you land.

The goal is to be the first to reach the center position, the family picnic spot.

Plain markers, but a nice board with great bright graphics for the era. And the early edition comes in a beautiful period box with a great painting of a car on the cover.

23744.name: Libido
23744.description: The spicy dicey adult game of strategy and luck! Contains 6 Libido™ dice cups 36 Libido™ dice, storage bag, and rule sheet. For 2-6 players.

23745.name: Down & Dirty
23745.description: The lusty "inspect and collect" adult card game. Contains 104 Down & Dirty playing cards and rule sheet. For 2 to 6 players.

23746.name: Cajones
23746.description: The adult strategy game that takes balls! Contains 1 playing board, 24 Cajones™ balls, drawstring storage bag, and rule sheet. For 2 players or teams.

23747.name: Bluff or Buff
23747.description: A bone-tickling, hilarious adult game of sexy revelation and high-stakes faking. Contains 124 Bluff or Buff cards, 16 playing chips, score pad, and pencil. For 2 to 8 players.

23748.name: Nice or Nasty?
23748.description: The adult sexy slang game for word freaks! Contains 104 Nice or Nasty cards, 1 Nice or Nasty playing board, 8 pawns, 8 pads, and 8 pencils. For 2 to 8 players.

23749.name: Bare with Me
23749.description:
Players reveal their sexy reasoning or complete "pointed" sentence stems in their own words. For instance, do you know what your lover or friends would write if asked to list 2 reasons for having sex on the first date? Or how would they complete the sentence "If sex was playground equipment, I'd be..." or "You know I'm feeling horny when..."? Winning the game is easy: be the first player to collect a token from each of the other players by correctly guessing their answer!

The game where you "Bare" more than your soul! Includes 64 game chips, 80 game cards, 1 die, 8 pads, 8 pencils and rule sheet. For 3-8 players.

23750.name: Pose & Disclose
23750.description: The Scandalous game for show-offs and posers! Includes 160 game cards, 2 dice, rule sheet. For 2 or more players.

23751.name: Steamy Scenarios
23751.description: The ultimate game of "What If?" Includes game board, 104 game cards, 8 game pieces, answer pad, 8 pencils and rule sheet. For 4 or more players.

23752.name: Stacked
23752.description:
The titillating game of strategy and conquest! Includes game board, 60 playing pieces, rule sheet. For 2 or more players.

Re-implements:

Focus

23753.name: Throws of Passion
23753.description: The hilarious 'Love Positions' Dice Game. Includes male and female dice, 6 'positions' cards, score pad, rule booklet, pencils and storage pouch. For 2 or more players.

23754.name: Fortune Maker
23754.description:
From the box: "The action packed stock market game for 2 to 6 players".

On a board with 2 tracks the players move around the outer track using a d6, landing on squares that let them buy/sell shares, move the share index or gain/lose money.

The inner track (share index) indicates how share prices are altering.

Players try to buy low and sell high, gaining dividends over time. If you get it wrong, you're bankrupt and out of the game.

The game ends when all but 1 player is eliminated or after a set period of time, the winner is the player with the greatest value of shares and money combined.

23755.name: Shocking Memory
23755.description:
Similar to the game Simon, Shocking Memory has eight panels instead of four and you get shocked if you make a mistake. This game is not intended for small children or persons with heart conditions.

From the publisher's website:
Put your memory to the test. Repeat the sequence of lights and sounds. Each round gets a little longer and harder. If you can't remember the sequence; thats too bad, we're so sad...ouch! With three speeds even the best players will be sweating.

23757.description:
NHL Ice Breaker is licensed by the National Hockey League and features the league’s 30 teams plus national teams. You get all the great action of the game on the ice with NHL Ice Breaker. Game play is built around CSE Games' specially-designed 54-card playing deck (52 standard suited cards plus two Jokers). Each action in NHL Ice Breaker is based on the basic principle of high hand wins. Opponents play their card(s) at the same time to battle for puck possession, and the player with the highest hand gets to execute his/her action indicated on the card(s) played.

As players win hands, the puck is moved up the ice (game board) and toward the opponent's net. Along the way, players may land on special “Ice Breaker” squares, which can shift momentum in an instant. Ice Breaker actions include penalties, big hits, turnovers or great passes. Once in the Shooting Zone, it's a classic contest of shooter versus goalie. Did you play your cards right?

NHL Ice Breaker separates itself from other hockey-based games in that it has a true hockey 'feel'. The game is both accurate and fast-paced. Combining elements of popular card games, players must decide how best to play their cards. Cards can be played individually, in pairs, two pair, or three-of-a-kind. It is up to the player to decide which cards to play and how to play them.

The learning curve of NHL Ice Breaker is remarkably low. Typically, the game is learned within a couple of minutes, aided by the built-in familiarity that the playing deck offers. NHL Ice Breaker is designed for one to four players, ages eight (8) and up.

For more information, check out www.csegames.com.
23757.name: NHL Ice Breaker: The Card Hockey Board Game

23758.name: Trylogy (The Twin Cities)
23758.description: Tryology appears to be a combination of trivia and abstract strategy. Shipped in a triangular box, just like another Osobo title Triopoly. They also seemed to love to produce black components, as evidenced by Tryology, Triopoly and Beverly Hills.

23759.name: Red Dwarf: The Card Game
23759.description: Red Dwarf: The Card Game is a print and play card game based on the BBC sitcom Red Dwarf. Cards are taken directly from the TV show.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Games Magazine Best New Family Game Winner
23760.name: Tricky Town
23760.description: Board game with a trick-or-treat theme. Each player has four pieces representing members of a family (mom, dad, boy, girl), and a deck of cards used to determine movement. All players flip a card simultaneously, with order of movement determined by characters on the cards. Players move the number of spaces indicated by the number on a card; odd numbers move only one piece, even numbers can be split evenly between two pieces. Spaces on the board result in the gain or loss of treats (victory points). Players can also acquire "trick or treat" cards which can be played for extra movement. Movement is restricted by a rule that a child may never be more than five spaces away from a parent. There are short cuts that may be taken only by a parent and child together.

23761.description:
Guadalajara, portrays the operations launched by the Italian CTV (Corpo Truppe Volontarie—Corps of Volunteer Troops) towards Guadalajara with the ultimate objective of taking Madrid and putting a rapid end to the Spanish Civil War. The unexpected and dogged resistance of the Republican Army, which was fully involved in a deep reorganization, caused the failure of this offensive, forcing the Nationalists to give up trying to storm the capital and making them take the long road by capturing the whole country before being able to declare themselves victorious.

After the failure of Franco's Nationalist troops to surround and conquer Madrid during the first months of the Spanish Civil War, Spain looked doomed to a long war of attrition. During this gloomy period, a new force made its appearance -- the motorized Italian Corpo Truppe Volontarie (CTV). Lavishly equipped and overconfident after its first successful performance in the fall of Malaga, the Italians thought they could quickly and easily end the war. Spain was not Abyssinia, however, and Madrid was not Malaga. The new People's Republican Army was no longer the rag-tag mix of militia units that had fought the Nationalists only a few months before. The Italians were repulsed after a fierce campaign fought under very tough conditions. Madrid was once again saved for the Republicans, and two more years of war would ensue.

Special rules regarding tanks, anti-tank defenses, flamethrowers, truck transports, traffic jams, morale, and panic will allow you to recreate the Italian offensive. Will you succeed where your historical counterparts failed? Will you break the Republican lines? Will your volunteers panic as they did in 1937? Prepare to fight what Ernest Hemingway considered one of the most decisive battles in military history.

Four scenarios cover the full campaign, the Italian offensive, the Nationalist "side-offensive", and the Republican counteroffensive which broke the spine of the Italian assault.

Guadalajara is the twelfth game in the Standard Combat Series (SCS) from series from Multi-Man Publishing.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 1-2 days
Hex: .6 mile / 1 kilometers
Units: Company to Battalion

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 32" full color mapsheet
One dual-side printed countersheet (280 1/2" counters)
One 8-page Standard Combat Series rules booklet, Version 1.7
One 16-page Guadalajara rules booklet
One Player Aid card
Two 6-sided dice

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium-Low
Players: 2-3 or more
Playing Time: 2-8
23761.name: Guadalajara

23762.name: World Bowling Tour
23762.description:
From rules: "As a Pro Bowler, you enjoy being on tour, playing tournaments, earning your living by doing what you enjoy most...bowling. You have as a goal, gaining a reputation as a top professional bowler and insuring that you can always earn a living through bowling."

Players move bowling pin shaped pawns on a track that looks like a bowling score sheet, participating in tournaments as they go, collecting money for setting records or meeting sponsors, paying money for purchases or hospital bills, investing in pro shops, and sometimes falling into slumps. For tournament play, a separate pawn shaped like a bowing ball moves along a separate tournament track that looks like a bowling ball knocking down two pins.

To win, players need to collect money and place first in at least one tournament.

The box cover pictures Don Carter and Paula Sperber, who endorse the game and were apparently popular bowlers back in the day.

23766.name: El Enigma de la Pirámide
23766.description:
The players begin their way through the Labyrinth, creating a route for themselves while trying to obstruct the paths of other players.
In the labyrinth which they are creating there are two types of tiles, blue and orange. In the blue ones mummies appear and must be dealt with.
When the players eventually cross the Labyrinth, they begin their way across the Shrine. There, they must confront not only more mummies but also rocks that fall. Both rocks and mummies cause a player to be wounded. The wounds are shown on the cardboard that each player has. When a player receives three wounds, the player dies and is out of the game.
After one reaches the Shrine there is a Treasure. The fist player to get it wins the game.

23768.name: Trio
23768.description: Trio is a challenging and tactical game for children. In this game you have to move scoops of ice cream around on the board, and try to place three scoops on top of each other in the order shown on your 2 cards. Every time you succeed you win a card. You can also block the other players, by placing a cherry on top of your scoops. Win the most cards, and you will win the game.

23769.name: Pirat
23769.description: The players try to place their pirates and barrels on the wobbly ship without knocking down the other pirates. A spinner is used to decide on what level the pieces should be placed.

23770.name: Revenge
23770.description:
Revenge is a collection of rules specifically written for warfare in the Middle Ages. From the Dark Ages to the rise of gunpowder, war was the sport of nobles who knew that virtue, leadership, and courage were the only principles of war.

Revenge contains three sets of rules each emphasizing a romanticized view of an aspect of medieval battle: Deus Vult is for field battles, Into the Breach for sieges and Sluys for naval warfare.

Deus Vult is designed for 15mm miniatures, each model representing 20 men, but can be easily scaled for use with 25mm miniatures. Meanwhile, Into the Breach is designed for 25mm miniatures representing 5 men each. Sluys is intended for 1:100 scale ship models and 15mm miniatures.

There exists also a supplement, "The Normans", which contains several scenarios for Revenge, but no new rules.

23771.name: Foggle
23771.description:
Foggle is a mathematical game using 16 dice and a shaker like the letter game Boggle. However in Foggle the dice have numbers instead of letters, and the object is to form valid mathematical equations.

Basic game :
Two or three dice are thrown to create the key number.
The players then have 3 minutes to find as many correct mathematical solutions as possible to generate this key number from numbers resting in a 16 cube grid.

Many different game variations are possible and are all described in the rules.

23772.name: Beware the Spider
23772.description:
The game uses a similar mechanic to Operation and takes two C-cell batteries.

The red molded plastic game base has a silver conductive web on which various plastic critters are placed. A felt spider is situated menacingly next to the web in its allocated position over a small hole, which contains a small mechanical lever-type apparatus inside.

Each turn, players attempt to remove a critter from the web with a pronged device which is connected to the board with a wire. If the surface of the web is touched with this, the circuit is completed, the mechanism in the hole beneath the spider is activated and the spider is launched. Any player disturbing the spider must replace the critter they were trying to get.

The player collecting the most critters from the web without disturbing the spider (touching the web with the pronged device) is the winner.

23773.name: Bop the Beetle
23773.description:
This old game comes in a huge box (20" x 13" x 5"). It consists of five components only - a large plastic clam-like frog with identical halves almost 12" long and wide; two thick plastic oval beetles 4" x 6" and two 20" long solid plastic tubes (the 'boppers'). The two halves of the frog are joined by a hinge at the rear which causes the frog to lock in an open position when set.

The beetles are placed on the ground an equal and agreed distance away from the set frog and must be 'bopped' into the frog using the plastic tubes provided. This is accomplished by whacking the plastic tube on an edge of the beetle, causing it to fly up in the air. The first player to successfully bop their beetle into the frog causes the frog to snap shut and wins the game.

23774.name: Mark Three
23774.description:
IDEAL's treatment of tic-tac-toe enclosed in a large 18" square box.

The large plastic gameboard consists of four gently sloping ramps which extend upward from each side of a tic-tac-toe grid. There is a circular hole in the center of each grid segment to accept players' discs.

Each player is given eight plastic discs of their chosen color and a device to release the discs (basically a circular piece of plastic with a raised slit) down their particular ramp. A turn consists of aiming a disc and releasing it down the ramp. Discs that fail to come to rest completely within a hole are removed from the board and used later if required. Only the top disc showing in any given hole counts in gameplay.

The first player to land three of their discs in holes so that they form a straight row in any direction is the winner.

23775.name: Bee Bopper
23775.description:
"BOP UP YOUR BEE BOP, WHEN THE SPINNER POINTS TO YOU...
I'LL TRY TO CATCH YOUR BEE AND WIN A CHIP OR TWO"

"Get ready! Get set! Play BEE BOPPER! One player bops their bee when the spinner points to their color. To win chips, opponents try to trap the bee before it is bopped, or catch the bee in their net after it is bopped. Who's the best BEE BOPPER? ...invite the gang around to find out!"

Players must try to increase their initial complement of ten chips to twenty by catching or trapping opponent's bees with their net. The first to do so is the winner.

The game comes in a large colorful box (16" x 14" x 3") with four nets, four bees, four bopping devices, a spinner and a supply of chips. Apart from the cardboard spinner base, all components are plastic.

23776.name: Tombstones n' Tumbleweeds
23776.description:
A character driven Western tabletop wargame by Game Werks. Players act out gunfights and other "Old West" scenarios involving a handful of distinct characters in miniature.
This game borrows many mechanics from other games, and thoughtfully blends them together for a easy to follow, yet comprehensive, miniatures game.
Like Mordheim, players are able to advance their characters, and play through many one off, or linked scenarios. Scale is 25mm.
Rulebook is available in print format, as well as a PDF download through RPGNow.com and Wargaming Online.

boardgamehonor: 2006 Origins Awards Vanguard Award Winners
2007 Diana Jones Award for Excellence in Gaming Nominee
23777.description:
Adventure and glory await you in Pieces of Eight, the rousing combat game of rival buccaneer ships on the high seas. You play the game with a stack of metal pirate coins held in one hand that represents your ship. The coins you choose and the order in which you place them determine your ship's strengths, and you use the special abilities of your coins to destroy your opponent's coins one by one. Your goal is to expose the Captain coin buried deep in the middle of your adversary's ship, then take him out!

Dare to enter the age of blood and gold with either The Blade or The Maiden's Vengeance ship set. Each set includes all the coins needed for one player to construct his own ship. Your opponents will each need their own ship set to play, but there's no other limit to the number of players who can join in. The coins in each set are not randomized; you can combine ship sets to gain a wider selection of coins and the advantage over your foes.

From the Atlas Games website.
23777.name: Pieces of Eight
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGB Volume 28 - Gheos, Pieces of Eight, Der Elefant im Porzellanladen

23778.name: Count Dino's Number Marathon
23778.description: Each player tries to move his herd of dinosaurs across the finish line first by rolling dice and counting. A player chooses a herd (all Stegasauruses or Dimetrodons or T. Rexes or Triceratops, etc. Each dinosaur in a herd is a different color: red, yellow, green, and purple. A player rolls four dice and puts them in any order he wishes so that they make a four-digit number. Then he moves each dinosaur along a separate colored path: the red dinosaur moves by the thousands digits, the yellow dinosaur moves by the hundreds digits, and so on. Then the next herd of dinosaurs starts their trek on the path to the finish line. Game variations allow for showdowns, "Dino Math Action," and "Prehistoric Problem Solving" for older children.

23779.description:
Times are great for the Candyman. He's just re-opened his factory, sold millions of nut-covered chocolate logs, and taught the world something about love. But too much is never enough. Now he's looking for a recruit from among his staff to pose as his arch nemesis, the Enemy Chocolatier. If you're good enough, that just might be you!

Players start at the Chocolate Factory and take over the city, one house at a time. Each neighborhood earns you money and points. What’s more, you get a little closer to completing your “secret recipe.” Enemy Chocolatier is a Euro-style strategy game with colorful, modular boards and lots of backstabbing and strategy!
23779.name: Enemy Chocolatier

23780.name: The Road Runner Game
23780.description:
The Road Runner Game consists of a deck of cards and 8 flat cardboard cutout figures of The Road Runner and 1 Wile E. Coyote figure, both characters from the Warner Brothers cartoons.

The cards are numbered and have brightly colored and patterned backgrounds (one background per set of numbered cards). The cutouts are about 10 inches tall.

The Road Runner and Coyote cutouts are placed in the center of the table. One less Road Runner than there are number of people playing are used.

The players try to collect a full set of numbered cards. The first one to do so lays his cards down and grabs a Road Runner figure. Everyone else grabs a figure as quickly as possible. The last person to grab a cutout (or perhaps a faster person, but one who grabbed the wrong figure) gets the Coyote.

23781.name: Professor Noggin's Countries of the World
23781.description: For those who know plenty about their own country, but want to learn about other areas of the world, Professor Noggin offers a trivia game on various countries, and their flags, capitals, languages, traditions, as well as the animals and people who inhabit them.

23782.name: Professor Noggin's Countries of the World 2
23782.description: A companion game to the original Countries of the World card game. Learn more facts about lesser known countries and the continents they belong to.

23783.name: Professor Noggin's Ancient Civilizations
23783.description: Professor Noggin steps back in time to explore lost but not forgotten civilizations. Discover facts about ancient places, philosophers, buildings, clothing, arts, and empires on a trivia-filled journey of discovery.

23784.name: Professor Noggin's Medieval Times
23784.description: What did the Magna Carta do for us? Who was Joan of Arc? How did one avoid being burned as a witch? Learn the answers as you travel back in time to a world of knights, battles, castles and cathedrals.

23785.name: Professor Noggin's Creatures of Myth & Legend
23785.description: Gryphons, basilisks and phoenixes all existed before Harry Potter. Learn about these mythical creatures and explore the science, religious beliefs and cultures that created them.

23786.name: Professor Noggin's Earth Science
23786.description:
Learn about the volcanoes, thunderstorms, and the crust of the earth as Professor Noggin tests your knowledge on Earth Science.

23787.name: Professor Noggin's  Famous Inventions
23787.description:
The world is made up of famous inventions. Professor Noggin looks throughout history to quiz you on how the most prominent inventions were made, and who made them.

23788.name: Professor Noggin's Wonders of Science
23788.description:
Professor Noggin takes Science out of the classroom and into this entertaining trivia game. See what you know, and learn surprising new facts as you go. Wonders of Science will create science wonderment for all who play.

23789.name: Professor Noggin's American Revolution
23789.description:
Professor Noggin offers a game covering the American Revolution, a happening that shaped the modern United States of America. No other children's game uncovers the significant events with such fresh, enlightening trivia facts.

Who were the Patriots?

23790.description:
From the Publisher's website:
Keeping in mind that in order to know which way we are headed, we need to know where we've been, this game has trivia on the battles, soldiers, and different aspects of the American Civil War.

Professor Noggin's series of educational games encourages kids to learn interesting facts about their favorite subjects. Each of the thirty game cards combines trivia, true or false, and multiple choice questions.
A special three-numbered die is included which creates interaction and promotes communications between players. Easy and hard levels keep kids interested and challenged - while of having fun!

23790.name: Professor Noggin's Civil War

23791.name: Professor Noggin's Freshwater Life in North America
23791.description:
Everything young naturalists need to know about life in the ponds, lakes and rivers of North America. Learn about River Otter, Wood Ducks, Mosquitoes, and Snapping Turtles.

23792.name: Professor Noggin's Pets
23792.description:
Puppies, kittens, lizards, and turtles are just a few of the popular pets that children long to adopt. Discover interesting facts about common pets, and learn about the proper care these pets need from their human parents.

23793.name: Professor Noggin's  Prehistoric Mammals

23794.name: Professor Noggin's Wildlife Safari
23794.description:
Professor Noggin embarks on an expedition of the most colorful, exciting animals in the world, such as lions, zebras, and elephants. The diversity of wildlife is tremendous in this adventurous game of the natural world.

23795.name: Professor Noggin's Reptiles & Amphibians
23795.description:
Professor Noggin explores some of the longest-surviving animals on earth. Lizards, snakes and crocodilians are just a few of the scaly, cold-blooded species that are investigated in this game.

23796.name: Professor Noggin's National Parks
23796.description:
Professor Noggin travels around to develop a game that celebrates our beloved parks, which have helped preserve history, heritage, and the natural beauty of North America for the enjoyment of all its citizens.

Eastern Woodland Parks

23797.name: Professor Noggin's Life on the Farm
23797.description:
Cultivate your mind with trivia questions from Professor Noggin’s Life on the Farm. Topics range from all aspects of farm life, including animals, plants, and machines.

23798.name: Professor Noggin's  Birds of North America
23798.description:
Test your knowledge on the warm-blooded, egg-laying, feathered vertebrates more commonly known as birds. Just because they all have wings doesn’t mean they’re all the same. In fact, Professor Noggin will give you a true bird’s eye view of what kinds of differences are found in these incredible creatures.

23799.name: Professor Noggin's Dinosaur
23799.description:
These prehistoric creatures will come to life in this game of frightening facts and deadly discoveries. Find out everything you wanted know to know about Dinosaurs, including what they ate, how big they grew, and how they defended themselves.

23800.name: Professor Noggin's Insects and Spiders
23800.description:
Insects and Spiders are some of nature’s tiniest wonders. Learn what they eat, where they live, and what makes them unique in this creepy, crawly Professor Noggin game that is guaranteed to keep you swarming with excitement.

23801.name: Professor Noggin's Outer Space
23801.description:
Professor Noggin delves deep into Outer Space, exploring plants, starts, and solar systems. Explore the cosmos in this challenging trivia game that will have you guessing about everything under the sun, and some things over it.

23802.name: Who Did It...?
23802.description:
Sharpen your pencils and prepare to test your wits. In a roller coaster ride aboard the Oriental Express a crime has been committed which only you can solve! Play the role of a famous detective - you could be Sheerluck Homes or Ivan Inkling! It's a hectic race from carriage to carriage as you seek clues and try to fit the missing pieces of the puzzle together.
Instant family fun, this captivating board game will thrill and entertain you as you rush to reveal who it was that dun the dastardly deed!

Contents : 5 foot lay out of a steam train game board, counters, pencils, mystery card deck, score pad, die, rules

23803.name: Chattabox
23803.description: In this fun, teasing race game, players attempt to play their cards while calling out solutions to given topics.

23804.name: Rhyme Thyme
23804.description: Rhyme Thyme is a fast-action matching game that will have you racing to get rid of your cards first. Spot a rhyme in another player's hand and be the first to call out the match. You will need keen eyes and fast hands to "catch the match" in this game.

23805.name: Beam Me Up
23805.description:
From publisher:

It's the Annual Alien Conference and the aliens are stuck on the moon without transportation. This is your chance to take an alien home! Maybe not your home... but it's your job to get the aliens back to their home planets. In this trick-taking card game the highest card wins the round. Call out "Beam Me Up" when you have collected three aliens from the same home planet and a Space Racer will come to the rescue. The player who send the most aliens home by the end of the game wins the title of Star Space Traffic Controller!

The game is played in rounds with each player trying to win tricks by playing the highest numbered card. For every trick won, the player who played the highest card gets to choose 1 card from the trick to keep and add to his Beam Me Up line. The object is to get 3 cards with matching elementals in your Beam Me Up line so a Space Racer can be launched to come and transport the aliens home.

23806.name: Camper Damper
23806.description:
From publisher:
It's time for a trip to the woods in this fun game where players scramble to complete their camping trips. Each game is different as you collect food, fun and shelter, while other campers try to sabotage your fun with Camper Dampers. Dodge all sorts of trouble from poison oak and sunburns, to grumpy bears looking for dinner in your tent. Whether by luck, skill or by spoiling the fun for other campers, be the first to finish your trip and win!

23807.name: Picture Spot
23807.description: It's a whole lot of fun trying to match the pieces of the modes of transportation together. Line up the puzzle cards with the right spot on the game board to reveal the whole picture. Children successfully complete the pictures by using visual clues to match the cards to their boards.

23808.name: Galebari
23808.description:
From the box cover:
It's summertime at Adriatic coast. Beautiful girls from all over the world came to enjoy sea, sun and good fun. And here they are... who will have more success? Local guys Roko, Stipe, Ante, Borna, Sale... or maybe you?
In this easy learning standalone card game player takes a role of "GALEBAR" - summertime playboy who competes in winning over lady tourists of most intriguing desires. (Based on true stories from Adriatic beaches.)
Deck consists of 94 cards (36 Ladies, 30 Approaches, 11 Places and 17 Events). When a Lady comes into play, each GALEBAR plays one of his available Approaches. Depending on Lady's Interests (Romance, Sex, Fun and Money), active Place and Event, each player counts his score. The player with the highest positive score wins over the Lady. The end winner is the player with the most Ladies won during the game.

23809.description:
Jetzt fahrn wir übern See... consists mainly of beautifully designed panels showing a picture that represents a children's song. One card is drawn each round, and the song is sung. The kids try to identify and grab the right tile, and the first one who does so keeps it. Whoever has the most titles at the end of the game wins!

The 2013 edition of Jetzt fahrn wir übern See... includes forty songs, with the complete text of each song.
23809.name: Jetzt fahrn wir übern See...

23810.name: Jo Müllers Kino Quiz
23810.description: The players race around the board and answer questions from various movie categories such as Quotes, Cult Cinema, Actors, Genre and so forth. Whenever they get a question right they can mark down points on their marking sheets. However answers a specific number of questions first is the winner. The game comes in a film spool packaging and includes a soundtrack CD over famous movie tunes

23811.name: Wordigy: A World of Words for Family Fun
23811.description: There are 130 cards, each with a letter and a value (values range from 1 to 5; the same letter can have different values on different cards). There are multiple rounds, with the number of cards dealt to each player increasing from 5 to 10 as the game goes along. Players draw and discard in turn until someone can spell a word using all but one of their cards.

23812.name: Drachenjäger von Xorlosch
23812.description: The Dragon Academy has prepared 13 difficult Quests, huge challenges that are made up of many single Tasks. Lead your group of dwarfs with skill and cleverness to achieve as many quests and tasks as fast as possible. With every successful quest your group‘s experience will grow to allow you to solve the later quests with greater skill. The group that fulfills the most tasks will win the game.

23813.name: The New York Times Crossword Puzzle Game
23813.description:
Players take turns solving crossword puzzle clues before their time runs out, and advancing their pegs along a cribbage-style track based on the number of letters that are in the words they have correctly solved.

The puzzles are actual New York Times crossword puzzles, edited by Eugene T. Maleska, having a copyright date of 1978, and there are 100 of them. Additionally there are another 20 "Junior Level" puzzles.

An approximately two-minute hourglass timer provides the suspense, and players select which clues to answer based on the values on four ten-sided dice.

The player who has advanced his pegs furthest along the track at the end of the game (e.g., when the crossword puzzle is completely solved) is the winner.

23814.name: B.S.
23814.description:
B.S. is a trivia game that asks players to distinguish the truth from the total B.S. "Is 'Batonophobia' the fear of cheerleaders?" "Do mice cry tears like humans?"

It is a combination of poker and of straight trivia. Players must determine which of 3 random facts is B.S. and they bet on their answers using poker-style betting chips.

Players can also draw "Total B.S." cards, which ask you to shout of out B.S when you think you know which of 5 statements read in a row is B.S.!

The winner of B.S. is the player with the most chips at the end of the game.

23815.name: National Geographic: Pictures of the World Card Game
23815.description: A simple trivia game on the topic of geography using cards with color pictures.

23817.description: 1861 is an 18xx variant set in Russia. 1861's defining characteristics include: 16 minor companies that are put up for auction during stock rounds, minors having the opportunity to merge or convert in to major corporations, and a non-player controlled government railway.
23817.name: 1861: The Railways of the Russian Empire
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episodio 14 – Especial verano 2014: Reglas mal explicadas
제108회 녹(에)취게임 - 18xx

23818.name: 1847: Pfalz
23818.description:
1847 - Pfalz is an 18xx game set in the German Pfalz area.

There are 4 quarries, train builder "Krauss &Co." and the directors of 2 of the 5 major companies (6 in a variant game) in the starting package.
The rules are similar to those of 1835 with a few exceptions concerning private companies, tile laying and some small other issues.

23819.name: Chalk Talk Hockey Trivia Game
23819.description:
This action packed Hockey Trivia Game is designed for hockey fans 8-adult. There are over 100 challenging questions on hockey rules and trivia. After landing on ChalkTalk or Locker Room Trivia and answering the question correctly, get ready to take a shot on goal! ChalkTalk's unique patented Mag-Action goal system makes a shot on the goalie a combination of luck and skill. It's an exciting race to put your hockey team together. The first team to have 6 players on their team bench is the winner!
For 2 or more players. Guaranteed Fun and No Skates Required!

23820.name: Dumbass!
23820.description:
Dumbass! is the kissin' cousin of the F*ck This!! card game, one level more sophisticated and two levels less raunchy (you can actually play it with your family).

Like the various "dumb crook news" stories, each player competes to perform the most inane stunts possible, the winner being the first person to get themselves killed or permanently incarcerated for their stupidity.

In addition, a custom expansion is available, with ten cards, and an Infinite Armies - like interface that allows you to completely customize each card before printing, allowing you to create a personalized deck with cards indistinguishable from the main game.

Both Dumbass! and the expansion are pdf titles, which are downloaded and printed on cardstock or the pre-perfed business card sheets available at any office supply store.

Expanded By:

Dumbass! expansion #1

23821.name: Show Off!
23821.description:
From back of box:
Players race around the alphabet game board, as they flip over category cards and place their chips on letters. You can only put down a chip if you can name something that begins with the letter that matches the category card in play. You get 1 point for each chip you can place. Whoever has the most points after 5 rounds wins the game.

There are three different games to play, including an advanced game where players can bluff their way around the board.

Contents include: pencil, score pad, game rules, 6 chip holder boxes, Show Off game board, 100 Show Off category cards, and 180 colored chips in 6 different colors.

23823.name: Hue Knew?
23823.description:
From back of box:
Match the color to the word – it's harder than you think!
Think you can think straight? Think again, in this fast-moving, fun-filled game where you have to spot the color name that's written in the correct hue. It's harder than it sounds – and more fun than you ever imagined!

Contents: 40 Hue Knew? disks, Cover disk, and 10 colored pawns.

23825.description:
(from page 2 of the rule book)

Timbuktu is a four-player strategic-level wargame simulating the rise and fall of empires in the gold-producing regions of West Africa during the period 1050-1550. Each turn represents fifty years, more than enough time for several changes of monarch. Therefore, players are not taking the part of a king. Instead, they represent the changing political goals of their Tribe’s collective leadership.

Players will quickly realize that this is not a game where one Tribe can build an empire and hold onto it for the length of the game. Historically, as soon as any political system becomes set, decomposition begins. In short, empires decline. The effect of economic inflation and administrative inefficiency is built into the game. Victory lies in creating as glorious an empire as possible and cutting losses when it falls.
23825.name: Timbuktu: Empire in the West African Sudan 1050-1550

23826.name: A Day at the Races
23826.description:
A Day at the Races is a novel if somewhat random attempt at creating the excitement of a race meet complete with betting on the family room table.

This game comes from the Crown and Andrews stable well-noted for their tabletop cricket simulation "Test Match" which has stood the test of time as the benchmark children’s cricket game that delivers strategy and fun through a heavily TOY based game. e.g.: manually triggering your bowler to bowl a ball which the batsman needs to manually trigger and hit to toy fieldsmen.

However a Day at the Races involves you clamping one end of the racetrack to the end of your table with two provided metal clamps and then pulling a tensioned green vinyl racetrack out until you can hook it over the other end of the table. Then it is a matter of setting up the other colorful bits such as the starting stalls, the finishing post and of course the five lovely plastic horses complete with weighted swinging jockeys.

Players then present their stall cards to get their starting places and have an opportunity to bet on who they think will hit the finish line first.

From here it is a matter of turning a crank at the starting line which causes the track to vibrate under the horses propelling them slowly forward, until a winner emerges.

As far as I can determine this seems entirely random (although the weighted jockeys seem to behave differently each time). Though the game would be a great beer and pretzels action affair or for those loving horse racing. Due to the random nature and betting I wouldn't really recommend for youngsters.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Fairplay À la carte Winner
23827.description:
Millionen von Schwalben is a (fairly satirical) soccer-themed game. Each player manages several soccer teams in a world championship tournament, trying to become rich. Matches are played with cards and die rolling, and different teams have different abilities. The action and country cards allude to many real-life events in soccer.

Even though team success in the tournament is rewarded, the 'big money' is made through betting on the matches. Interestingly, the referee (another player) places bets, as well...

The game also contains 54 soccer-themed cards for Anno Domini published independently as Anno Domini: Fussball WM.

Available microbadge:
23827.name: Millionen von Schwalben
boardgamepodcastepisode: Millionen von Schwalben Review

23828.description:
Gather your armies and fight over 3 positions. Cards represent infantry or cavalry regiments or artillery batteries. The uniform colors and styles are the uniforms that the regiments actually wore (according to the designers). You also have cards representing the participating generals , terrain and the ever present special events.

Dixie is a collectible card set but with a flat rarity. This is the third set with 250 cards for the Battle of Gettysburg.

All artwork and graphics in the Dixie series was created by RPG/Historical artist, Eric Hotz (www.hotzartworks.com).
23828.name: Dixie: Gettysburg
boardgamefamily: Dixie: American Civil War Card Game

23829.description:
Dixie is a collectible card game but with a flat rarity. This is the second set with 400 cards for the Battle of Shiloh. Complete sets are also available and individual cards may be ordered through the Columbia Games web site. All artwork and graphics in the Dixie series (each regiment card is drawn with its historical uniform) was created by RPG/Historical artist, Eric Hotz (www.hotzartworks.com).

The Dixie system is an expanded version of Columbia's tactical battle board system used in such games as Napoleon: The Waterloo Campaign, 1815. Each unit card shows its unit ID, its Combat Value (CV--the number of dice rolled), and its Firepower (the number needed to hit a target).

The game is played without a board; the table is divided into three battle line areas for each player (left, center, and right). Players deploy cards face down into their three battle line areas. Player's hands act as the Reserve area. Each turn, every unit may either move or fire. Movement consists of advancing into the opponent's battle line areas to engage. Combat consists of rolling dice equal to the unit's CV with hits occurring for each die that is less than or equal to the unit's firepower. For each hit taken, a unit must make a morale check, rolling equal to or less than their CV or "rout" (i.e., be discarded).

Play continues until one side is able to occupy unopposed two of the three opponent's battle line areas. Rules are included for fighting a second day.
23829.name: Dixie: Shiloh
boardgamefamily: Dixie: American Civil War Card Game

23830.name: Fairy Meat Components Pack
23830.description: The component pack expansion for Fairy Meat provides additional materials to accommodate up to 8 more players. The bundle contains fairy cards, life counters, twinkle counters, and kill counters for use in the game.

23831.name: Ruck Zuck
23831.description:
Ruck Zuck, the quick cardgame.
Try to get rid of the cards in your hand by placing them on a board. The one that first has an empty hand wins.

23832.description:
Svenskt brädspel (Swedish Tables), more commonly known as just Brädspel or Bräde, is a Backgammon relative native to Sweden. It's the last surviving member of the 17th-century Verkehren/Revertier family of games, that mainly differ from Backgammon in forbidding the closing of the first eleven points - making it possible to win by "locking out" one's opponent, called jan in the Swedish terminology. Brädspel adds to Verkehren a third objective - arranging one's pieces in one of four preset patterns - and rules for hitting a closed point under special circumstances.

A Brädspel table was brought aboard the warship Vasa on her ill-fated maiden voyage in 1628. When the ship was salvaged in 1961, that board rekindled interest in the game, helping it survive where other Verkehren games died out. Today, the game is governed by the Swedish Tables Association of the Vasa Museum, which holds annual championships right next to old Vasa.

RULES:
(Slight variants may exist. These rules are based on the (lengthier, complete) rules used in the Swedish Championships.)

The game consists of a board (similar to a backgammon board), 15 checkers (game pieces) each of two colours for a total of 30 pieces, and 2 regular dice.
A full match is usually played as best out of a predetermined odd number of games. Winning a single game gives 1-4 points as described below.

The fields are called tongues and are numbered from 1-24 for each player, starting with 1 at the top right tongue as seen from the player, and going counterclockwise around the board with 24 in the lower right corner. Tongue number 1 is called a player’s ”home” and number 12 is referred to as "huk". Fields 1-6 constitute the first quarter, 7-12 the second, 13-18 the third, and 19-24 the fourth.

Preparations: Each player choses one color and places all his/her 15 checkers on his/her home tongue in the upper, right corner. The starting order for the first game is determined by rolling one die each after which the player with the lowest result goes first. In consecutive games the loser of the previous game starts.

Gameplay:
The players take turns throwing the dice and (if possible) moving their pieces. The game pieces are moved counter-clockwise according to the dice. If a player is able to make a move it is obligatory to do so. If only one die can be used it is mandatory to do so. The player can choose to move the same piece for both dice or move a different piece for each die. If moving the same piece for both dice it is forbidden to add up the the numbers and land immediately on the field corresponding to the sum. The piece has to be moved first according to either of the dice and then according to the other. If both dice show the same number they are counted double, e.g. if two fives are thrown the player moves 5 + 5 + 5 + 5 steps and the player can distribute these four moves freely on 1-4 game pieces.

There must never be game pieces of opposite colors on the same tongue. A player may have no more than one game piece each on tongues nr 2-11, and once the home has been reduced to one game piece the same applies to that field. On tongues 12-24 the number of the player's own game pieces is unlimited. If a game piece lands on a tongue with a single opponent piece, that piece is ”beaten,” meaning that it is temporarily taken out and has to re-enter the game by landing on a tongue in the first quarter that is either vacant or has a single piece of the opponent’s colour. (See exception under blasting – b below) No other moves are allowed for a player with one or more beaten pieces until they are all back in play.

Two or more pieces of the same colour on a tongue are referred to as bands. A game piece may normally not land on one of the opponent's bands. (Exception explained under ”blasting” a-b below.)

Blasting:
Though it is not normally allowed to land on a field containing a band of the opposite colour there are two exceptions. Beating more than one piece at once like this is called blasting.
a) If a player has bands on six or more consequtive fields the opponent may beat all the pieces on one of these fields by landing on it.
b) If the opponent has bands in a player’s first quarter and the player’s only opportunity to get all his beaten pieces back into play is by landing on one or more of the opponent’s bands he is allowed to do so, blasting the opponent’s pieces.
If a player has exited all pieces but one from the game it is no longer allowed to blast with that last piece.

Winning conditions:
There are several different winning conditions (five if counted as below) plus the possibility for a player to surrender a game. A surrendered game gives one point to the winner. A player can surrender at any time as long as he has not yet formed any band in his third or fourth quarter. After doing so surrendering is no longer allowed, even if the band(s) has/have since been broken.

1. "Home play" Exiting the board with all 15 checkers. (1 point for winner)
Once all of a player’s pieces are in the fourth quarter he can start taking them out of the game by throwing at least the number required to reach an imaginary 25th tongue. (If a piece is beaten at this stage it has to re-enter and move all the way into the fourth quarter before any furher pieces of that colour can exit.)

2 ”Beautiful game” (1 point for winner)
There are four different winning conditions referred to as "beautiful game" which are all obtained by arranging the game pieces in specific patterns in the fourth quarter. They all give one point to the winner. Both dice must be counted, i.e. a player can not win this way by only moving for one of the two numbers thrown. However, if a player can win through ”beautiful game” by casting one die only he may chose to do so. In case of failiure he may only cast one die on each of his two following turns. The four variants of beautiful game are:
2a. Three pieces each on tongues 20-24
2b. Five pieces each on tongues 22-24
2c. Three pieces on tongue 22, five pieces on tonge 23, and seven pieces on tongue 24
2d. All fifteen pieces on tongue 24.

3. "Monk" (2 points for winner)
3a) ”Homeplay with monk" Winning by homeplay while the opponent has at least one beaten checker not yet back into gameplay.
3b) "Beautiful game with monk" Winning by beautiful game while the opponent has at least one beaten checker not yet back into gameplay.

4. "Jan" (2 points for winner)
If a player beats more of the opponent’s pieces than can possibly re-enter the game (due to a lack of available tongues in the first quarter) that player wins the game. This is called ”making the opponent Jan”

5. "Blast-Jan" (4 points for winner)
Making the opponent Jan by blasting a band.
23832.name: Svenskt brädspel

23833.name: Talstafet
23833.description: The game consists of: 1 board, 1 red die, 1 blue die, 1 playing piece, 35 number tokens, 1 set of rules. The one who gathers most points wins. Move a playing piece around the board and get as many number tokens as possible before the board is out of tokens or your piece cannot move anymore.

23834.name: Ordfejden
23834.description:
Ordfejden, Swedish for "the word feud", is a dice based crossword game by the Swedish snack-company OLW. Including timer, 15 dice, score sheets and rules it was given away as a freebie when buying two packs of OLW snacks.

Ordfejden is a word dice game.

23835.name: Futbol Cacho
23835.description:
This a little dice game that we play in our town (Oruro, Bolivia), the popular name is Capi Futbol because it's based on another dice game called Capi Manda (or The Captain give orders) that is kind of like poker dice...

In order to play you just need 5 dice, a cup, and you have to draw a sketch of a football pitch (divided in 5 areas: goal area - field - midfield (the mid line does is not a divisor line) - field - goal area) and a counter that represent the ball (we almost always use a bottle cap).

The game starts with the "ball" at midfield. After a "toss" the one who has the kick off shakes the dice in the cup and the other player does the same (always after the one who is the Captain at time), then the non-captain player can re-roll from 1 to 5 dice, after he does the captain can do the same, they both can no use the re roll (see SIT DOWN below).

This way they play "poker hands" with rankings like this: 5 same (Grande), 1 different (Poker), 2 same 3 same (Full House), 1,2,3,4,5 or 2,3,4,5,6 or 3,4,5,6,1 (Escaleras, in ties the higher straight wins, 3 of the same (Tricas, 111 the higher, 222 the lowest), pairs, if neither of you has anything then both players put all the 5 dice in their cup and play simultaneously with no re-rolls with highest winning.

Every time a player wins a hand, he moves the ball one space towards the opponents goal area.

When you are playing in the goal area if the Attacking player wins it's a goal, you can play to a certain amount of goals,or with a time limit.

suggested optional rules.
DESPEJE (Shot from the goal keeper) after winning a hand in his own goal area a player may choose to made a Despeje.

If he does he rolls one die and moves the number of pips in spaces towards the Goal area of the opponent, but when it reaches the goal area then the ball goes back towards the field (some people choose to not let the ball go back to the goal area or field of the shooter).

After this shot the opponent keeps possession and is now the Captain).

SIT DOWN (Mid distance shot at the goal) there is no re roll if you are in the "Field" area next to your opponent's Goal area, if the attacker wins its a goal (some people prefer to Announce the shot before a SIT DOWN happens), if the defender wins it's a DESPEJE but this time the defender keeps control after the play.


3 LINEUP CHANGES to represent the 3 substitutions of players allowed in a football match, the player can Voltear (turn a dice over to its opposite side) 3 times in a match (i.e. a 3 can become a 4 if using a change, a 2 can become a 5, a 6 can become a 1 etc.) Some people let the attacking player do 1 Volteo each hand if he desires except when he is at the opponent's Goal area.

Well this game is fun and you can play it anywhere (because it is a modified game of Generala it's like our national game) and of course it's about luck but not pure luck.

23836.name: Conjecture for Kids
23836.description:
The "model" game for enhancing a child’s creativity. Based on the best-selling original Conjecture, Conjecture For Kids is designed for younger players. The object of the game is to sculpt modeling dough into a topic identified on your game card in hopes that your team can guess the right answer before your opponents.

This game offers parents and teachers a wonderful tool to help children develop hand-eye coordination, and teach them to associate imagery with words.

Similar to the classic game of Pictionary, only using sculpting dough rather than drawings, Conjecture For Kids offers hours of entertainment for parties of all sizes. To assist the artistically-challenged, we permit the sculptor to make motions with the dough, however noises (aside from laughter) are forbidden.

The hilarious game features two varieties of uniquely scented dough that will last several years if maintained properly, and because it is water based, it won’t make a mess.

23837.name: Sudoku Taisen 6x6: The Great Battle of Sudoku
23837.description:
Taisen, a Japanese word for Great Battle. Now you know ... But are you ready? Are you ready for the Great Battle of Sudoku!

Sudoku Taisen is a true multi-player sudoku game. 6x6 grid with 1,000+ ways to play and you are the puzzle!

In Sudoku Taisen 6x6, it is much more challenging to complete your grid because you are sharing 8 squares (shared squares are called Taisen Square) with your opponent(s). Your opponents can place a number to prevent you from completing your grid. Therefore, you need to stack your opponent's number with your desired number, so you may complete your grid. Your opponents will surely do the same to you. Furthermore, additional challenge, your fate of winning also depends on your dice roll and the Taisen Card you draw.

Contents:
20 Taisen Cards
180 Chips
1 Die
1 Board (two sides)
1 Manual in English

Board is designed for two or four players. It can also be used for one player and three players.

Related to:

Sudoku Taisen 4x4: The Great Battle of Sudoku

23838.name: Complete Tiddledy Winks
23838.description:
This is a deluxe version of Tiddeldy Winks with a bowling variant.

It can be played as the regular game in which players try to be the first to snap all three of their winks into the cup.

Or the Target Tiddeldy Winks variant can be played using the target board and cup, which are neatly set into the box bottom so that the cup is roughly flush with the target surface. In this variation the first player to 100 points wins, with higher points being achieved by the concentric rings of the target or the cup itself.

The Tiddeldy Winks Bowling game is what makes this unique. In this variation the target/cup remains in the box, but a cover is placed on the cup. Atop that cover sits a red bowling pin with a separate wide circular base. Nine white pins are placed on the marked circles around it, forming the ten pins of a standard triangular bowling arrangement.

Players try to snap their winks and down the pins. Ten points are awarded for the red pin, and one for each of the white pins. The player with the highest total after ten rounds of three winks snapped wins the game.

23839.name: Boar Hunt: The Dark Ages
23839.description:
Boar Hunt:The Dark Ages Game is a game that appears simple at first glance because there are only 9 spots on the board and 8 playing pieces which all remain on the board during the game after they've been placed.

Boar Hunt has two teams of 3 Dark Ages "Hunters" and a "Wild Boar". One player plays the red set and the other plays the white set. The object of the game is to be the first player to capture their "Boar" between 2 of their "Hunters" either going across the board or along the outside circle.

The game is played in 2 phases as in a 9-Mans Morris Game. The players take turns placing their Boars and Hunters on the board and if no one wins in the placement phase, the players take turns moving their pieces to capture their own Boar between their own Hunters while trying to block their opponent from winning.

Though there have been countless games through the centuries which use a small format game board (Mu Torere and TicTacToe to name 2)but Boar Hunt is the first that uses 2 teams trying to achieve different but similar goals.

Boar Hunt:The Dark Ages Game started out as a small game with a leather "Acorn" board with glass playing pieces packaged in an attractive wood box.

The deluxe version features a solid wood game board with nice details and the playing surface is burnt into the wood using the "pyrography" decorating technique. The playing pieces are hand finished castings of the original playing pieces which look like they were carved in the actual Dark Ages. The playing pieces have a nice heft to them and the game is quite attractive when set up.

The size of the board (6"x9"x3/4" - 16cm x 23cm x 2cm)and the sculptural quality of the playing pieces will make this an attractive game to leave set up on your desk, coffee table or bookshelf.

23840.name: Sebastopols Belägring
23840.description:
SEBASTOPOLS BELÄGRING. Nytt slags schackspel.
Ett underhållande tidsfördrif för ungdom och i sällskapskretsar.
Detta nya spel bildar en övergång från Dam- till Schackspelet samt ger eger ökadt intresse genom att bildlikt framställa den krigsskådeplats, som fortfarande tager vår samtids hela uppmärksamhet i anspråk.

Nytryck 2001, Armémuseum Stockholm.

In English:
THE SIEGE OF SEBASTOPOL. New kind of Chess.
A amusing pastime for youth and society.
This new game is a link from Checker to Chess and tries to visualize the battleground, that still claim all our society's attention.

New print 2001, The Swedish army museum Stockholm.

23841.name: Games of the World
23841.description:
GAMES of the WORLD has been Chris's pet project at Acorn Games for years. Acorn Games has always wanted to produce a game with a solid wood board and playing pieces that allow you to play a multitude of games.
